Problem:
Investigate the causal relationship in a system where the state vector \\( z \\) evolves according to the linear partial differential equation \\( \\frac{\\partial z}{\\partial t} + M\\frac{\\partial z}{\\partial x} = N z \\), where M and N are constant matrices. The influence of a Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F}(z) \\) is applied which initially alters the state by converting space-domain information in z into frequency-domain.

If \\( \\mathcal{F}(z) \\) is performed on \\( z(x,0) \\) and it evolves according to the given differential equation, will \\( z(x,T) \\) at time T be equivalent to allowing \\( z(x,0) \\) to evolve under the same conditions without applying \\( \\mathcal{F}(z) \\)?
Explanation: Applying \\( \\mathcal{F}(z) \\) changes the representation of \\( z(x,0) \\) from space to frequency domain, thus altering the initial conditions under which the differential equation operates. The evolution path and the eventual state at time T will differ due to this transformation of initial conditions.
